Award.AwardTitle: CISE EAGER: Achieving Realism in ns-3 Wireless Network Simulation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Network simulation continues to be an indispensable tool for performance evaluation of wireless network protocol stacks for it's ability to explore fine-grained causal input-output relations and network scalability aspects, that cannot be readily studied by other means. This project will add much needed ingredients to ns-3 (the most commonly used open source simulation tool for networking research) and extend its capabilities beyond those in comparable commercial tools in important ways.

Network simulation methodologies face a fundamental dilemma - increased realism only comes with greater simulator complexity. The pathways proposed provide the best, most realistic approaches to achieving a proper balance. The agenda broadly concentrates on a new wireless protocol stack library that efficiently incorporates cross-layer design approaches that capture the coupling between parameters at Layers 1-2 and protocol elements at Layers 3-4. Further, coupled simulation-emulation approaches that balance the flexibility of the former (software simulation) with the fidelity of the latter (testbed or emulator) will enable new design and performance analysis techniques. All freeware will be disseminated via the ns-3 website (www.nsnam.org) under usual GPL and publicized via tutorials at conferences and workshops.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A testament to NSF CISE's long standing commitment to development of research infrastructure has been the support for  ns (current release ns-3.24), the most popular open source network simulator within the academic research community; (see www.nsnam.org); the current project's specific aims were to contribute new wireless modules that addressed emerging wireless heterogeneous networking scenarios, i.e. enable coexistence studies between different network technologies. Given the current impetus for spectrum sharing, such scenarios are of immense interest, as are cross layer(PHY/MAC) inspired solutions that enhance such sharing.While a significant academic literature on this topic has developed, very few (if any) of these methods have found their way into  ns-3. Our work was thus very timely as it attempted to bridge this gap. 

The fundamental achievement in this project was to integrate the SPECTRUM framework into ns-3.The distinguishing features of this framework is that a) the channel model is device  independent, and b) hence allow injection of multiple signals on the same channel (where the signals carry both a frequency and time-domain representation).  This constitutes the 1st step in defining a 'cognitive' wireless node endowed with channel awareness, which will enable exploration of a broad class of co-existence solutions. Second, there was no LTE module in ns-3 representing a serious shortcoming from the research community's perspective; this gap has been eliminated. For further information, see

 https://depts.washington.edu/funlab/projects/improvements-to-ns-3-simulator/
